HEY!!! Stop lumping Harry Potter in with *Twilight*! :P

Guys… you REALLY need to drop everything until you've read Dune.  In terms of absolutely required geek-reads it should be up there on the shortlist with the likes of LotR and HHGTTG.  (But arguably it's always been more approachable than Tolkien, and is less tied to a specific time period than the Hitchhiker's Guide.)

Something that really bugs me about the reading habits of Harry Potter Slash Twilight Generation (several times in recent years my mention of Dune has been repaid with a blank look):  If it hasn't been a Major Multimedia Cross-Merchandising Event in the decade since the internet and fandom really took off, it can't be any good.
Okay, done, I'll read it after Dance.
Mr_V, what's your verdict on the Dune sequels?

I'm a lot fonder of them than many others are, that's for sure.

Look, Dune itself stands alone as a stunning classic, and Herbert never again quite regains the same pace and inventiveness.  That said, the original trilogy (as it once was) is well worth reading, and God Emperor draws a very fitting line under the whole thin.

Heretics and Chapter House to some extent feel like an unnecessary continuation of the story, though it is interesting to see Herbert taking his whole universe into the realm of long-view SF.  I, personally, still found a lot to like in those two books — they introduce a unique and memorable new cast of characters, for one.

Possibly the "secret" is to read the whole lot in fairly quick succession while you're entirely immersed in the universe.  I did, and I never reread any of the books except Dune itself.  I'm guessing it may be harder to get into the later novels if you're not "living" right there, begging fore more story/details.

I'd advise everyone to read up to Children, at least.  Don't give up during Messiah — it's a typical "middle book" of a trilogy… it provides a bridging narrative without much really happening.  Things pick up again in Children.

If you're still hooked on the universe by the end of Children, you'll love God Emperor.
The books co-authored by Brian Herbert and Kevin J Anderson after Frank Herbert's death are utter drivel, by the way.
Thanks, that's good to hear.
I still enjoyed Dune way more than any of the other books in the series. Though I only touched Frank Herbert's books and none of the others.

While I'm on the subject, it's worth noting that Gemmell is probably one of the post-Tolkien fantasy authors with the best claim to real literary merit.

If you liked the concept of the Dark Tower series, but found the execution less than compelling (*puts up hand*), you could do (much!) worse than reading David Gemmell's Jon Shannow novels.

Note that the three Shannow books are in fact the 4th, 5th and 6th installments in a larger series called the Sipstrassi Tales, but it's entirely possible to read the Shannow books (set in the far future) first, and then read the two preceding books (set in Arthurian times) as prequels later.  (I did.)
